title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 1, 2019).

Endo, J&J and other drugmakers that face sprawling litigation over the opioid crisis are exploring a way to settle the cases by participating in Purdue's bankruptcy.

WeWork is planning thousands of job cuts and other measures to stop bleeding cash after a failed initial public offering attempt and the ouster of its CEO.

Facebook plans to exempt opinion pieces and satire from its fact-checking program as it seeks to stop the spread of falsehoods while maintaining its neutrality.

The social-media giant plans to pay only a minority of publishers whose headlines will be featured in its coming news section.

Aramco is targeting potential nongovernment investors with plans to pay a total annual dividend of $75 billion as it builds toward an initial public offering.

The S&P 500 eked out a modest increase in the third quarter, helping stocks hold on to their biggest year-to-date gains in more than two decades.

Blackstone will buy a portfolio of U.S. industrial warehouses from Colony Capital for $5.9 billion.

Fannie and Freddie will start keeping earnings as part of the process of returning the mortgage-finance firms to private hands.

Budweiser Asia shares rose in their trading debut in Hong Kong, giving the brewer a market capitalization of about $47 billion.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires
